Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Engaged Student Learning-Design and Development Level II: Using a Cyberlegarning Environment to Improve Student Learning and Engagement in Software Courses

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Due to the ubiquitous nature of software in the 21st century there is a great and increasing demand for software developers and programmers in the US. Both Computer Science (CS) and Information Technology (IT) academicians and practitioners agree that a comprehensive strategy to improve the number and quality of 21st century CS/IT workforce is needed. This project will assist colleges and universities in producing more well-qualified software developers through the use of a cyberlearning environment that builds on and extends WReSTT-CyLE (Web-Based Repository of Software Testing Tutorials), a cyberlearning environment for software testing.

The project will: (1) investigate the impact that students' use of WReSTT-CyLE, at a cross-section of academic institutions, has on their software testing skills; (2) develop a theoretical framework of learning and engagement strategies that best support improvement of students' knowledge and skills in software courses for diverse student groups; (3) transform WReSTT-CyLE into a domain-independent cyberlearning environment for software and programming courses (SEP-CyLE) and repeat (1) above using SEP-CyLE for software courses; and (4) conduct biannual workshops to expose instructors to how SEP-CyLE may be used in the classroom to support pedagogy. The research in (1) will include mixed methods studies with both qualitative and quantitative components.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes of the Project

Due to software's ubiquitous nature in the 21st century, there is a great demand for software developers and programmers in the US. The Bureau of Labor Statistics projects the number of software developers will increase by 22% from 2012 to 2022, much faster than the average for all occupations. Computer Science (CS), Information Technology (IT), and Software Engineering (SE) academicians and practitioners agree that a comprehensive strategy to improve the number and quality of the 21st century CS/IT/SE workforce is needed. This project scales up an NSF Transforming Undergraduate Education in STEM (TUES) to improve students' learning outcomes in CS/IT/SE by providing them access to a cyberlearning environment (SEP-CyLE – Software Engineering and Programming Cyberlearning Environment). 

SEP-CyLE provides students and instructors access to vetted learning content (learning objects and tutorials) using a combination of learning and engagement strategies (LESs). These LESs include collaborative learning, gamification, problem-based learning, and social interaction. Collaborative learning - two or more people work in groups mutually searching for understanding and solutions to a problem. Gamification - uses game design elements to improve user experience and engagement in an educational context. Problem-based learning - an approach to learning and instruction in which students tackle real-world problems in small groups under a tutor's supervision. Social interaction - enhances knowledge acquisition through social activities, such as students establishing dialogue within student groups and teachers.

The main goals of this project are (a) to determine the impact the LESs used in SEP-CyLE have on a cross-section of student groups (from multiple institutions) using appropriate research techniques, and (b) to apply the positive effects of the research to software engineering and programming using SEP-CyLE. To accomplish these goals, the project team:

  1. Extended the cyberlearning environment developed in the TUES project.

  2. Developed a framework to integrate LESs into learning activities in the classroom.

  3. Hosted faculty professional development workshops.

  4. Conducted research studies to determine the impact using SEP-CyLE, at a cross-section of institutions, has on students’ conceptual understanding and practical skills in software engineering and programming courses.

Cyberlearning Environment: SEP-CyLE (https://stem-cyle.cis.fiu.edu/) currently has 3,755 users (49 instructors and 3,702 students); 56 course shells – templates created for courses at different institutions; 160 courses were created using the course shells; and 2,472 students submitted a total of 34,901 learning object assessments that were graded. The learning content (learning objects and tutorials) developed during the project and hosted in SEP-CyLE can be viewed at https://stem-cyle.cis.fiu.edu/resources

The project team developed a framework for integrating LESs into different teaching modalities, including face-to-face, online, hybrid, and synchronous remote. This framework has guided several of the project’s research studies and has been used in additional grant proposals seeking funding to continue this work. The framework is presented as an optimization problem. Given a specific learning environment and teaching modality, there is some combination of LESs that will produce the optimal student learning outcomes. Through research, these combinations of LESs will be refined over time to deliver the best possible results.

Faculty workshops: During the project six (6) faculty development workshops were conducted. These workshops are titled “LESSEP” - Using Learning and Engagement Strategies in Software Engineering and Programming Courses (https://stem-cyle.cis.fiu.edu/events). Four of the workshops were conducted at FIU, one at the Association for Engineering Education (ASEE) conference and one at the ACM Richard Tapia Celebration of Diversity in Computing. The participants of the workshops came from 20 different institutions, including Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs), Historically Black Universities and Colleges (HBCUs), and Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR) state institutions.

Several studies conducted during the project showed very promising results. Studies conducted with students at two universities, one a large HSI, in software testing and introduction to programming classes showed that using SEP-CyLE to support in-class activities improved students’ conceptual knowledge and practical skills in software testing techniques and testing tools. Other studies showed that using different LES combinations in SEP-CyLE produced different results for different types of classes. For example, in a software engineering senior class, the combination of collaborative learning, gamification, and social interaction had the greatest impact on student learning. While in the introduction to programming classes at several institutions on the project, gamification and social interaction had the most significant impact. Details for all the studies can be viewed at: https://stem-cyle.cis.fiu.edu/publications

The institutions participating in the project are: Alabama A&M University (HBCU); Florida A&M University (HBCU); Florida Gulf Coast University; Florida International University (HSI); Georgia Southern University; Miami University; North Dakota State University (EPSCoR); and Virginia Commonwealth University (VCU). As a result of this project's success, the team will be applying for a grant proposal to transform undergraduate education in the CS/IT/SE community.
